Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2009 02:53PM - edited Sep 5, 2009 02:55PM by Krisc Hi Rebecca, I am sorry you are dealing with this alone, that is very difficult.  I am a high risk, diagnosed with LCIS a few months ago.  I remember how terrified I was waiting to find out what was going on.  You are in my prayers.  The lumps may be just like last time ---benign!!!!  The majority are benign and hold on to that!   Try not to think of it....I know that is hard because you want to try to get as much info as you can.  Just a word of advice, stay away from here until you know something for sure.  Really, I should have, I worried myself silly, expecting the worst possible outcome from my biopsies and MRI. Don't get me wrong, this site is so valuable, and the posts are very helpful and so are the people, but until you know what you are dealing with, it is way too much information.  Information that you may not need, and alot of the information is freightening. Just ask God to give you peace and guidance and enjoy your sweet little ones and have fun this weekend.  {{{{{{{HUGS}}}}}}}} Kris

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2010 02:43AM - edited Jun 19, 2010 03:54AM by Krisc KORYNH My diagnosis was not DCIS but LCIS.  LCIS is treated differently than DCIS and is not considered a cancer, but a "marker" for increased chances of  developing breast cancer in my lifetime, my oncologist says about a 25% to 30 % chance over the average woman.  I see a breast surgeon and oncologist every 6 months.  I also have a digital mammogram and MRI on alternating 6 months.  I also take EVISTA to hopefully help reduce the chances of developing breast cancer in the future.  Pretty scary diagnosis, yes, but I consider myself somewhat lucky to be able to be monitored so closely and should breast cancer develop, hopefully it can be detected at a very early stage. Trust me, I am not downplaying my diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2010 07:16AM Krisc wrote: Traci, I know how you are feeling.  If the radiologist said a BIRADS 4 and then a 2 after that he may be referring to a rating of 4-b.  4's are broken into a, b, and c.  I had a Birads 4B last year.  Went through all the tests, and ended up with lobular carcinoma in situ.  This is not breast cancer but at a higher risk of developing it some time in my lifetime.  Relax.  The biopsies are not that bad.  I am small busted too and had no problems.  Because you are an "A", it is a little more difficult to get a hold of your breast for a stereotatic biopsy.  My aunt is very small, she was told the same thing, but they were able to do it. Like others have said, 80% are benign.  also if the clusters do represent a cancer, it is usually in a very very early and very treatable stage.  Best of luck to you.
